@willl1038  Limits, derivatives, continuity, some integration
Assume the weight is 1 unit

(k-1)st block doesn't have weight (k-1). It's the weight of (k-1) blocks. The weight of (k-1)st block is just 1. (k-1)Ck-1 means we consider (k-1) blocks as one unit, which has it's centre of mass at Ck-1 and weight (k-1).
Thank you!

NIceeeee!!!!!

Unfortunately, we don't have video recording of these recitations, but you can review the PDF materials in the full OCW course site http://ocw.mit.edu/6-042JF10 in the recitation section -- take a look at #12.

You've probably long forgotten this since it's been a year but maybe this comment will help someone else in the future. You want to look at the limit as the functions approach infinity in f(x)/g(x). Since 1/ln(x) approaches 0, we don't use theta. He provides the example (x/100) = theta(x) and this should help demonstrate what IS theta. f(x)/g(x) = (1/100 * x) / x = 1/100 when you cancel the x's out, so you can use theta here since it is between 0 and infinity. You could also use Big Oh in this case and still be correct.

That becomes f = theta(g). It means that f is tightly bounded between its upper and lower bounds. The tighter the bounds the better (Variance will be low).

In the base case, you assume n = 1, f(n) = f(1) is nothing more than a scalar. So, in any step, say, when n = a, f(a) is a scalar.  That is to say, you use induction cuz you wanna prove a base case and extrapolate it further and further, but in every step, what you prove is a scalar f(a) = O(1), its like "a constant is always big O of another constant."
就是说所有用asymptotic notation的等式都是标量式，都不是一个方程。用数学归纳法永远证明不了这样的结论的？？
我就是类比以前用归纳法证明的例子，带入n，左边是一个1到n的和的方程，右边是一个带一个常量的n的方程，我没过他就是一个数我想的是未知量n啊，这样方程就是关于n的方程，而不是数啊。
I have just finished the next course.It says it makes no sense to specify n in the predicate.& Never use asymptotic notion in a inductive hypothesis.Never mix the big-oh to the predicate,
I understand .It seems like a function.But when you put an N into it.That's the end.There's no next step. Is that right?

对，就是这样，数学归纳证明不了你想证的（不是说这个过程是错的），因为在归纳的每一步，你都把数字带入了方程。比如F(n) = n ^ 2; G(n) = n 通过数学归纳证明的就是，n = 1时，F(1) = 1; G(1) = 1 , 1 = O(1)成立，n = 2 时，F(2) = 4; G(2) = 2, 4 = O(2)成立，n = 3时 9 = O(3) 即使n 到 n + 1 也成立，你证明的也只是：一个由F(n)生成的常数永远是由G(n)生成的常数的big O。
